Report Considered

Every student has by this time received and (it is
hoped) read a report issued by the Student Council concerning its activities during the first semester. It is good
that the Council has seen fit to enlighten the student body
on its work; it is courageous that they have done so in
yieNv of the lack of real accomplishment shown therein.
How the writer of the report can blithely remark that
"the major accomplishment of the Council was the sponsorship of the Student-Faculty Camp" when it is a wellknown fact that much of the work of organization of the
camp was completed prior to their taking office, we can't
understand. Similarly, we find nothing to indicate that
the "Council has shown marked interest in the race problem." It hasn't been mentioned since last spring.
It is interesting to note that "after a poor start due
to personnel difficulties, the SC Assembly Conference
Committee is now functioning smoothly." Our only question: Where are assemblies?
Other matters mentioned by the report are steps forward (additional members on the Goucher-Hopkins Coordination Committee; expanding the activities of the Public Relations Committee) but these are small steps forward
in view of what the Council could do and has not done.
What the Council omits from the report is that topic
about which most of its meetings have revolved this
semester: the SAC-SC relationship—a problem which,
as of now, has yet to be solved.
Whatever the case, the Council has failed to come
up with new ideas, to provide speakers for assemblies,
and, worst of all, has failed to settle the contradictions
within its own house. This week, in its last meeting of
the first semester, the Council again had to hold an
"informal meeting," due to its inability to obtain a quorum.
This is the third time this semester it has had to do so.
Three Council members now have collected the maximum
of absences permitted, and the number of "excused"
absences listed after the names of many others is depressing to behold.
It is no wonder that the report of first semester activities is disappointing. The members of this year's Council,
it would seem, simply aren't taking their jobs seriously.
Unless they begin the second semester with a completely
different attitude, their year-end report may be even
:worse.
